Tort (French word means ‘wrong’)
A civil wrong not arising from a breach contract; a breach of legal duty that proximately causes harm or injury to another.
Tort law recognizes that some acts are wrong because they cause injuries to others.
Business Tort: wrongful interference with another’s business rights
Cyber tort: a tort committed in cyberspace
Cyber Tort - Online Defamation
Most cyber tort involved defamation.
Defamatory statement on business policies and product - posted in online forum, SNS.
These channel allow anyone-customer, employees or crackpots, keyboard warriors to complain while remaining anonymous.
Initial issue , WHO DID IT?
In real world easy to identify the author
To take action on this online defamation, need to discover the identity of the person who posted the defamatory message
An ISP - can disclose personal information about its customer only when ordered to do so by court.
Usually business or individuals are bring lawsuits against John or Jane Doe.
Then using the authority of the courts, the plaintiffs can obtain from ISPs the identity of the persons responsible for the defamatory messages.

Contracts are agreements that the law will enforce.
Contracts are individual, or private, rights and duties created by oral or written agreement and consent of the parties.
Contracts may include obligations imposed by law even if the parties are not aware of those obligations.
How to Approach Contract Law?
Contract law follows the dictates of common sense and fairness.
After looking at all the facts and circumstances, you should answer the following questions:
Was there an agreement?
What did each party commit to do?
Did either party – or both – fail to do what he or she promised?
If yes, how do you measure the cost to the nonbreaching party?
The usual objective of remedying contract claims is to put the parties in the position they would have occupied if the contract had not been breached.
What are the Different Types of Contracts?
Express Contract:
The promises are communicated by language, either oral or written.
Johan promises to paint Danial’s car in return for Danial’s promise to pay him RM1000.00.
Implied Contract:
The conduct of the parties indicates that they consented to be bound.
Siti fills her car with gas at Rina’s gas station. There is a contract for the purchase and sale of gas.
Unilateral Contract:
A person accepts an offer by performing a requested act. The terms of the offer must clearly indicate that an act is required for acceptance.
Johan tells Danial that he will pay Danial RM1000.00 if Danial paints his car, and that Danial should show acceptance of the offer by the act of painting the car. Danial accepts by painting the car.
Bilateral Contract:
A person accepts an offer by promising to do the requested act.
Red Company offers to buy 100 widgets from Green Company for $100. Green Company promises to deliver the 100 widgets to Red Company.
Elements of a Contract
When a party files a suit claiming a breach of contract, the first question the judge must answer is whether a contract existed between the parties.
One of the parties made a promise to do or refrain from doing some specified action in the future.
Something of value was promised in exchange for the specified action or nonaction.
This can take the form of a significant expenditure of money or effort, a promise to perform some service, an agreement not to do something, or reliance on the promise.
Consideration is the value that induces the parties to enter into the contract.
The offer was accepted unambiguously.
Acceptance may be expressed through words, deeds or performance as called for in the contract.
Generally, the acceptance must mirror the terms of the offer.
If not, the acceptance is viewed as a rejection and counteroffer.
